social_posts.post_text:
Leave a 👍 in the comments if you’re going to try this out. Also, I’m hosting an online program nect weekend on “Mastering Stress and Anxiety.” The dates are Dec 9-11.

I will share daily teachings on a variety of different topics and practices, including:

✅A novel interpretation of stress & anxiety that goes against the mainstream

✅Highly practical tools and strategies for working with acute and long-term stress

✅Meditations and visualizations to release and soften years of dense stress accumulation

✅How to form a calm, grounded relationship with the part of you that feels stress/anxiety

✅The subtle ways stress shows up in the body even when our mind feels fine (and how we miss it)

✅A deep dive into the neuroscience and spiritual interpretations of stress/anxiety

✅Guided hypnosis meditations to facilitate release, letting go, and deep rest

✅How to use guided imagery to relax the nervous system

✅How to create the inner safety necessary to navigate life from a calm/grounded place

✅Everything you need to know to begin and sustain a meditation practice

And much more.

I also want to make sure you have all the resources you need to feel supported after our retreat. So, in addition to 11.5 hours worth of teachings and practices, you’ll receive over $500 worth of post-retreat gifts:

✅A Customized “Anxiety” Meditation
✅3 Relaxation Meditations
✅Lovingkindness, Tonlgen, and Compassion Meditations
✅A Meditation for Befriending, Integrating, and Releasing Inner Demons
✅20-Minute “Deep Rest” Meditation
✅COVID-19 Self-Care Kit (meditations & practices)
✅30-Minute Video Teaching on the 3 Stages of Relaxation
✅10 Different Guided Mindfulness Meditations
✅5 Sleep Meditations
✅10-Day Deep Sleep Course
✅31-Day Mindfulness & Positive Psychology Series
✅7-Day Anti-Anxiety Coaching Series
✅8-Page Mindfulness Starter Pack
✅30-Minute Partner Meditation Practice 

All sessions will be recorded and yours to keep forever. So, if you’re interested in the content, but are not available, you can register and review the recordings, resources, and bonuses when it’s convenient for you.

Learn more at the link in my bio or go directly to https://corymuscara.com/retreat/ 

Big love.

A note about my Teacher:

Sayadaw U Pandita passed away in 2016. While I often resisted his intense style of teaching, I had the deepest respect for him, and I always knew his intensity was coming from profound compassion for the suffering of humans, and his hard-earned wisdom that there was a way out.

Through his teachings, my life changed in ways I can’t describe; a sentiment echoed by thousands of others. 

I am forever grateful.

A post like this could not possibly capture the depth and nuance of this experience, so please forgive the social media format that encourages distillation over prose.

I will aim to offer more nuanced explanation and examples of these points in future posts.

You can follow along @corymuscara

And if this post resonated with you, please click the share icon above to add this to your story (if you think it will resonate with others) or share your thoughts on it below, especially with lessons stood out most for you🙏🏻 

Big love,
Cory

P.S. I also send short teachings like this every day in our text community on mindfulness, life design, healing, and personal growth. They’re completely free, go out every day at 11am EST, and you can unsubscribe at any time. To sign up, text the word “Growth” to 1-631-305-2874 📲

Curious what this zen proverb makes you feel? What does it bring up in your body? What does it make you reflect on? Share your thoughts in the comments ❤️ 

Also, we just wrapped up the live version of the 8-Week “Working with Thoughts” online course. It was an incredible, immersive experience, with over 16 hours of teaching content, 8 hours of Q&A, 32 customized meditations, 5 intuitive movements sessions, and more.

It’s all complete, recorded, and bundled in our new, interactive teaching platform (which also has it’s own app!).

And I’m making the course available for registration for a few more days before closing it down and sealing the container for participants.

So, if you’re interested in taking a deep dive into transforming your relationship with your mind—difficult thoughts, negative thoughts, rumination, stuck trauma, anxiety, intuitive guidance, and more—this is the last opportunity to access this course. You will have life-long access to the content after registering.

There have been many testimonials that have come through, but here’s a recent one: 

“Before the course, you said it was intended to be life-changing. And it has been. My life is completely different than it was when I started, and I’m so grateful to you for that.” -Amanda

You can learn more about the course at the link in my bio or by going directly to: https://corymuscara.com/course/ 

Big love,
Cory

Peace is a byproduct of softening into reality.

If you like getting thoughts and tips like this, I send them daily in our text community on the topics of personal growth, mindset, healing, and spirituality. People say it’s one of their favorite parts of the day. They’re completely free, no strings attached, and you can unsubscribe at anytime. To join, text the word “Instagram” to 1-631-305-2874📲

The intersection of self-love and self-change has always been interesting to me.

I don’t have all the answers to it. I think the two inform each other, each taking the lead at different times.

But I have noticed, as a culture, at least historically, we have emphasized changing yourself as the path to loving yourself. And that, I’ve seen, to be problematic and one-dimensional. We may feel motivated to change from a place of shame or self-hate, but we end up reinforcing the neurosis that tell us we’re not good enough, often leaving us with the same psychology, and the same core wound, even when we do make the changes we intended.

Self-love aside (or viewed through a different lens), when it comes to how change happens in an organic, aligned way, I take more of a self-determination theory approach, which essentially states that we feel the highest motivation when 3 basic needs are met—Autonomy (a feeling of having choice), Competence (a feeling of having skills), and Relatedness (feelings of closeness and belonging).

This still remains one of the most robust theories of human motivation available.

And as far as my investigation into has gone, self-hate doesn’t actually facilitate any of these 3 basic needs. I’m not necessarily saying self-love takes care of all of them, but I believe it takes us much further than self-hate.

So, when trying to change a patterns, see if you can start by feeling your self-frustration, taking a breath, and say, “I’m here with you. I care about you. I’m proud of you. What would it look like to take this next action from love?”

Try it out.

Big love,
Cory

Sustainable peace cannot come from the conditions of our life, because the conditions are always changing.  Peace comes when you are no longer tethered to the changing conditions of your life. When your sense of identity is more vast and expansive than the momentary shifts in experience.

Of course, we can make many shifts to the external world that go a long way in helping us feel more safe, connected, and at ease. But there is no amount of arranging the conditions of our life that will do the work of cultivating a mind and heart that is equanimous, free, and connected to the truest version of yourself.

*Note: The author of this quote in anonymous

I send short teachings like this every day in our text community on mindfulness, life design, healing, and personal growth. They’re completely free, go out every day at 11am EST, and you can unsubscribe at any time. To sign up, text the word “Instagram” to 1-631-305-2874 📲 

*It’s also the last 24 hours to get 50% off my Life Makeover Masterclass. It’s a great way to start the new year. Check it out at the link in my bio 👆

Big love,
Cory

Raise your hand if you feel this 🙋🏼‍♂️🫣

Associating capacity with obligation is why we burn out, stay in unsatisfying relationships, tolerate unfulfilling friendships, don’t put up healthy boundaries, and slowly overextend ourselves in toxic ways under the guise of virtue (I have the capacity to do this).

Remember, building your capacity for discomfort is a different journey than learning to discern your needs, boundaries, and desires. The two must be done simultaneously.

If you only build your “capacity,” you’ll use it to override your desires. If you only get clear on your desires, you won’t have the capacity to hold the discomfort that comes with their pursuit.

Share your thoughts in the comments 👇

When we are caught in shame, pain, self-hate, and unsafety, we engage in patterns that serve a fear-based part of us—We date the same kinds of people who reinforce the narrative that we’re not worthy of love; we work ourselves into the ground because we don’t think we have value unless we prove our “worth”; we eat too much unhealthy food because it numbs the pain in our hearts; we overexercise because it’s the only thing that gives us a sense of control; etc.

When we mend our relationship with ourselves, what motivates us is no longer fear and safety, but rather our natural life force—intrinsic motivation, curiosity, compassion, excitement, care, etc.

If you want support in this process, I have a 2-hour Masterclass on how to develop Self-Love at the link in my bio ❤️🎧

I reckon we could view this as the definition of living on autopilot. Most of us don’t even realize we’re on autopilot because inherent to that experience is a lack of awareness. 

One of the early gifts of mindfulness practice is that it shows us just how unmindful we usually are. A painful discovery, perhaps, but it’s the only doorway into a more intentional, conscious way of living.

The journey toward stillness is one that requires patience, compassion, and deep respect for the parts of you that have learned it’s not safe to be here—in your mind, in your body, in this existence.

If you’d support on that journey, join me for the “Finding Stillness” Masterclass that takes place Thursday, February 2nd, 7-830pm EST (you do not need to attend live to sign up; all registrants will receive lifelong access to the recording).

To learn more, click the link in my bio.

Our resistance to stillness shows up in different ways:

-Restlessness
-Impulsive behavior
-Fear of being alone
-Depletion of energy
-Addiction to being busy
-Constantly feeling empty
-Excess fidgeting and agitation
-Avoidance of once’s thoughts & emotions
-Difficulty with silence in conversation and life

I’ve spent a lot of time exploring stillness through nearly 10,000 hours of meditation, and subsequently, a lot of time learning about, and working with, all the reasons we avoid stillness.

It’s been incredible to discover just how difficult true stillness is, and just how many issues, internal and external, come from avoiding it (which I have deep empathy for).

As Blaise Pascal said, “All of humanity’s problems stem from a person’s inability to sit quietly in a room by themselves.”

So, I’d like to offer you a roadmap. Or, perhaps better put, insights from my own journey, and the journey offering this work to others.

If this topic calls to you, I’d love to have you there, live or on the recording.

Learn more at the link in my bio or directly at www.corymuscara.com/masterclass

If you’d support on your stillness journey, this is the last call to join the “Finding Stillness” Masterclass that takes place Thursday, February 2nd, 7-830pm EST (you do not need to attend live to sign up; all registrants will receive lifelong access to the recording).

To learn more, click the link in my bio.

There is a deep, healthy power that becomes available to us when we’re less dependent on other people or external things to feel worthy and whole. It’s the same sort of power that one has in a negotiation when they’re willing to walk away. When you’re less dependent on something or someone else for your self worth, you can engage with people and things from a place of spaciousness and love, rather than constriction and fear.

I say “less dependent” because we are still interconnected creatures, and there will always be some form of dependence on the world and people around us for our sense of wholeness and integration. I’m still thinking and feeling through what that line is. What I do know, for sure, is that self-love is a powerful force for healthy relationships and healthy engagement with the world around us.

If you want support in this process, I have a Masterclass on Self-Love at the link in my bio 🙏🏻

📷 Picture template artistry: @iamnotanartist_

I’ve noticed something in recent years...

As our understanding of growth and healing has deepened and complexified, it’s caused many of us to minimize the potency of small, simple, consistent actions in our development and success.

I’m guilty of this, too. Big time.

I want the perfect workout program so I don’t reinforce dysfunction in my body, but as I wait for that, I end up hardly exercising at all (even though I already have SOME things that I know are great for me).

I want the perfect journaling prompt that gets me oriented to my day in all the best ways, but as I wait for that, I end up not writing at all (even though I already know journaling my gratitude feels great).

I think aspects of this “waiting” can be wise, like the Abraham Lincon quote: “If I only had an hour to chop down a tree, I would spend the first 45 minutes sharpening my axe.” 

But we can become so obsessed with the sharpening that we never end up chopping.

And the reality is, much of our personal development is quite simple. We know what would be good for us, and we just need to do it. More and more.

It may be a more boring truth, but this is what the zen folks mean when they say “chop wood, carry water.”

We have to show up and put in the reps.

This is how the brain changes.
The body changes.
And our relationship to ourselves and life changes.

Of course, these “reps” don’t have to be a forceful, “no pain, no gain” approach. Sometimes, reps look like taking 10 minutes in the morning to stare out of a window & practice softening your body’s tension instead of looking at your phone and getting more wound up.

Or maybe your “reps” are working with a trauma therapist once a week.

Or maybe they’re hitting the gym. Breaking a sweat. Writing a few pages of your future book.

You can refine your approach as you go. But if your approach is good enough to start moving the needle, well, maybe it’s time to begin. 

If you’d like more support and encouragement in this process, I send free, daily text message teachings on mindfulness, life design, & personal growth. They’re completely free and you can unsubscribe at any time. To sign up, text the word “Instagram” to 1-631-305-2874 📲

One definition of trauma is "Too much, too soon, too fast." 

This definition must also be considered when trying to heal trauma. 

If, during our healing work, we take an overzealous approach, and open the flood gates to all the emotion or pain that we've understandably suppressed over the years, we won't have the inner resources to meet and integrate that pain, and it can be re-traumatizing. 

So, we want to meet our emotional pain in bits (titration) and develop the skills to re-ground when we feel overwhelmed (pendulation). 

One of the best ways to do this is to first spend time establishing a sense of safety and grounding in your mind & body before taking the journey of turning toward your pain. 

Create a "home base." 

Maybe the breath, the feeling of your feet on the ground, or looking at a picture of someone who makes you feel safe. 

Focus your attention to one of these places until it creates a feeling of safety and ease. 

From there, you can turn toward your pain--a difficult emotion, a triggering memory--and just practice meeting the corresponding feelings with compassion and presence. 

If it feels too overwhelming, return back to your home base, and repeat the process until you feel less "charge" in your mind and body. 

For more in-depth trauma therapy, I recommend EMDR or Somatic Experiencing.

And if you’d like more support, I send short teachings like this every day in our text community on mindfulness, life design, healing, and personal growth. Performative confidence comes from the ego. And the ego is a set of beliefs about who we need to be and how we need to act in order to be safe, loved, and praised. Ego confidence requires the validation of others, which is why it’s showy and performative.

This does not mean if you have true confidence that you do not share your skills or values. If you run a business, this requires you to “advertise” yourself. And a fear around sharing your worth is just as much an ego move as performative sharing of your value.

But there’s a difference between sharing who you are from a place of “This is what I can offer, I believe it’s impactful, and you can make your own decision about if there’s something here for you or not” vs “This is what I can offer, you should love me for it, and I need your praise to feel settled.”

Real confidence has a receptive, magnetic energy. Performative confidence has a graspy, outward energy.

If you’d like more tips like this, I send daily teachings on mindfulness, mindset, and mental health in our text community. They’re free and you can unsubscribe at any time. To join, text the word “Instagram” to 1-631-305-2874 📲

To be human is to live in paradox. And I believe our inability to accept this is what causes so many issues in our relationships and world. Think about it…

We must care deeply, but also let go.

We crave to be trusting, but also need boundaries.

We’re connected to everyone and everything, but also have differences that impact our lived reality.

We cannot rectify these paradoxes. We can only expand our mind to hold the full spectrum of polarity.

Unfortunately (but understandably) our tendency is to collapse into the comfort of more simple, but partial truths (one end of the polarity)/

This will not serve our collective evolution of consciousness, nor will it serve us in finding common ground and living in greater harmony.

The practice of presence (holding the fullness of your life) isn’t just for your personal benefit. The wellbeing of our relationships, our communities, our environment, and our world depends on our capacity to not disconnect from experience when it becomes too burdensome or complex. Everyone can be present for the good stuff. It takes a well-trained mind and heart to show up or the whole thing.

AND…

Growing our minds to hold more nuance and complexity is rarely relaxing, peaceful, or fun.

More often than not, it’s tense, aggravating, and painful. We’re pushing against our existing psychological constructs, which exist in their current dimensions because it’s what we’ve learned is right and safe.

How do we grow our mind beyond its current dimensions?

When you find yourself getting defensive, ask 4 questions: 

1.) What do I know currently believe is true here?

2.) Is it possible that there is another truth?

3.) Can I spend a few moments staying present to both of these truths at the same time?

4.) What does it feel like to do this in my body, and can I allow myself to relax into it?

Thank you for your practice.

Big love.

Share some love to your friends and mentors by tagging them below 👇 And if you need some friendly support yourself, you’re welcome to join my free text community to receive daily, encouraging messages on mindfulness, personal growth, and mental health. Register: corymuscara.com/heart

In the course, we explore:

➼ Heart-based practices to cultivate love
➼ Heart-opening sequences to soften the heart’s walls

➼ Daily strategies for monitoring when your heart closes and simple practices to invite it to open
➼ A 30-Day meditation plan to receive more love and openness
➼ How developmental trauma can condition the heart to close, and practices, tips, and science-based ways to heal and open
➼ Guided visualizations to feel the depth to which you can receive love

➼ And much more.

Waiting is a spiritual practice. It stems from your uncompromising commitment to inner truth. In the early stages of healing, self-awareness, and re-embodiment, expect (and give yourself permission for) a lot of waiting. You’ve been out of touch with your inner knowing for years, perhaps most of your life. Of course it’s going to be confusing. Of course you won’t yet know if you should take the job, or have kids, or be in the relationship, or take the call with your dad. So, let yourself be in the pressure cooker of not knowing; the spiritual waiting room. Be still, be patient, and only act when you receive a thread of clarity. Then follow it as deep and far as it will take you. Until you lose it again. Then you’re back in the waiting room. It’s not wasted time. It’s the complete opposite. It’s fully showing up for your time, being in your life 100%, and not defaulting to the easier, but disembodied compromise that keeps you half-heartedly floating through life.

Permission to not know, and to only proceed when something feels aligned, has been one of the most, if not THE most, important offerings to myself on the spiritual path.

Big love ❤️

Associating capacity with obligation is why we burn out, stay in unsatisfying relationships, tolerate unfulfilling friendships, don’t put up healthy boundaries, and slowly overextend ourselves in toxic ways under the guise of virtue (I have the capacity to do this).

Remember, building your capacity for discomfort is a different journey than learning to discern your needs, boundaries, and desires. The two must be done simultaneously.

If you only build your “capacity,” you’ll use it to override your desires. If you only get clear on your desires, you won’t have the capacity to hold the discomfort that comes with their pursuit.

Share your thoughts in the comments 👇

A common question I receive is, “Ok, now that I’m aware, what do I do?”

It’s an understandable question, and it has a place in our growth, but in my experience, the mind that is asking that question misunderstands (or has a limited understanding) of how real change happens. As if seeing a pattern, interrupting it, and doing something different is going to fundamentally reorganize how your system relates to the world.

I’m not completely dismissing pattern interrupt. I do it. It’s important. But if you’re not taking the time to feel, embody, and relax into the YOU that is required to be in the new pattern—the beliefs, values, and energetic experience of being someone who does this pattern—these pattern interrupt strategies can become exercises of will, temporarily suppressing impulses until your ego strength tires enough to default to what the system finds most familiar and safe.

That’s not real change. It’s a bandaid. Except nothing is actually healing beneath the surface, at least on an emotional/energetic level (suppressing the will to go on a bender might heal your body temporarily, but it isn’t addressing the source of pain).

So, what happens when we make the intention to simply bring embodied awareness to our patterns?

We learn about them. 

Not just on a cognitive level, but a full body, nervous system level. We learn about the triggers that push us in a certain direction, the way the mind convinces us this pattern is RIGHT, the terror and unsafety we feel when considering NOT doing the pattern, the ways the pattern may actually be serving something deep in us, the ways it’s causing more destruction than we realize, all the things the pattern is protecting, etc.

You can’t learn this through will and suppression. You can only learn it through curiosity, getting closer to the thing you most resent.

And, as frustrating as it may be, you’ll often need to go through the same loops over and over to realllllly get to know the pattern. But each time you do, you’re learning. The system is gaining wisdom. It’s seeing more clearly what ACTUALLY leads to freedom and what leads to suffering. It’s reorganizing around… [Continued in Comments]

social_posts.post_text:
Our ego structure likes control, and likes thinking that it knows what it’s doing. We’ve all seen the limits of this of course, and in many different contexts. But our recovery strategy tends to be some sort of psychological jiu jitsu to help us regain a sense of control, meaning, or clarity over our situation. Unfortunately, most of that clarity is just a temporary arrangement of outer variables aligning with our ego’s new construct for how the world should work.

Recognizing the limits of our ego structure--personality, conditioning, defense mechanisms--to usher us toward genuine fulfillment and freedom is the beginning of letting go, listening deeply, and surrendering to a different kind of truth that can guide your life.

Godspeed.

Everyone, I'd like to introduce you to someone.

This is Brianna.

My woman.
My soul partner.
My soon-to-be wife.

There is so much I want to share with you about this human--

> The way she looks at flowers & puts her hands on trees as if they were lifelong friends

> The precision of her intuition

> How deep she makes me laugh

And so much I want to share with you about how we got here--

> The magnetism that drew us together

> How much we each had to grow & transform to actually receive the truth of being together

> How unrelenting we were in our commitment to only be together if it were in truth

> How many painful loops we went through trying to make our relationship work, following the few feet of light we could see in front of us while we navigated the dark.

It's been an incredible, beautiful, and at times painful, confusing journey.

I'm grateful to have lots of opportunities to share about this journey with you, and for this to be the beginning of you getting to know the person I will be building my life with, and who has impacted what you've seen of me more than anyone or anything else over the last 5+ years.

To arrive where we are now, in complete truth, with all we've been through, brings me to tears.

I keep asking, "Is this real? Did we ACTUALLY make it? Is it possible that I'm this lucky to get to experience this kind of love and clarity?"

Yes. It’s real. 

But it isn't luck. 
It's the byproduct of being in truth.
We walked through the fire to get here.

Proposing to Brianna wasn't a decision. It was a receiving. It was the clearest knowing I've ever had. And it took more than 5 years for that knowing to present itself.

So many times it seemed like it wasn't meant to work. 

And we were both willing to let go if we needed to.

But we followed what was given.
We stayed in sequence.
We did not bypass.
We surrendered.

And in February, after fully letting go, the clearest knowing presented itself.

Spacious. Non-forced. True.

It was incredible.

And here we are.

Thank you to the many people who supported us along the way. You are our village.

I love you, Brianna. I’m honored and blown away that I get to do life with you.
Do not fear the self-love path.

Rumi talked about living at the threshold of life—that place between what is known and unknown, what is safe and what is new, the mysterious force that pulls us despite the rest of feeling resistant.

If you live at the threshold of your life, you will regularly experience a terrifying excitement. You will feel your aliveness. You will be asked to surrender, over and over, until your life is fully guided by something other than your ideas.

Not everyone is looking for this. But everyone has access to it.

My life’s purpose is to live at this threshold, and my life’s work is to share what I learn.

If you want more support, you can access the “Living in Alignment” masterclass, along with 100+ meditations, audio courses, and daily video coaching in our app. Join in my bio.

Big love,
Cory

Feel this in your body. Feel the cast of your ego structure tremble and tighten in its resistance to what a deeper part of you knows to be true. Let it fight, but stay present to the life pulse that is asking to come through. The density of your human will soften as it learns to trust the wisdom of your soul.

Big love ❤️

If you want more support, you can access the “Living in Alignment” masterclass, along with 100+ meditations, audio courses, and daily video coaching in our app. Join in my bio.

Sometimes, the most true experience we have access to in the face of pain is how much we hate it. So, we start by present with that. Allowing ourselves to meet the resistance, until it cracks us open into anger, and then sadness, then grief, then letting go, or wherever the internal thread takes us, without agenda.

This is how you stay present for your life even when you hate it. And it's how you get to the end of your life and say, "I really lived it. The life that was mine to live."

If you want more support, you can receive daily video coaching in our new Practicing Human app (see last slide for an example) along with monthly masterclasses, Q&A, guided meditations to help you get into alignment, and more. Learn more in my bio.

Often our biggest fear of letting go is not knowing what’s on the other side. That’s okay. Trust the internal wisdom that says something needs to shift, to be released. Let that be enough to guide you into the next mysterious unfolding of your life 🙏🏼

If we're not grounded, our entire life can be guided by media-, family-, and cultural-driven storylines.

This shows up as “noise” in our mind—reactive thoughts and emotions that push us into decisions that are only aligned with our superficial conditioning. 

When making decisions, notice all the ways your ego mind convinces you of what will provide freedom and contentment. 

There's no amount of luxury, security, amenities, good weather, or praise that can fill your heart.

All of this you can have. But it can’t be the organizing force for your pursuit of inner freedom. It will never work.

Practice being still. Become attuned to the many voices swirling inside you. Sensitize yourself to the one that is coming from a place deeper than your ego mind. The one that, when you hear it, feels frighteningly true. And then notice all the ways you try to negotiate that away, because you’re scared of what you would have to release if you actually let it guide your life.

Here with you ❤️

Who you are is bigger than what you experience. A simple practice you can use to help you connect to this spaciousness is mental labeling.

When you experience anger, say “Oh, this is anger.”

Fear? “Oh, I’m experiencing fear.”

Confusion? “This is what it’s like to feel confused.”

To be able to name the experience requires stepping outside of the experience. Try it out.

Thoughts are not the obstacle, they are the opportunity. If the peace you find in your meditation practice is contingent upon not having thoughts, you’re never actually learning how to find freedom within the human experience; you’re just perpetuating the cycle of preferring one experience over another, believing that there is an inherent self that can be attacked or agitated by phenomena. True awakening requires seeing through this illusion, and thoughts are a great place to start.

The selflessness of selfishness.

For more support on your self-care journey, text the word “Instagram” to 1-631-305-2874 for free text and audio message teachings 🙏🏻

At the level of the ego/self/personality, we can think of safety as the permission to be ourselves—to feel what we’re feeling without incurring pain that we’re unable or unwilling to feel. This safety is what allows all the various parts of us to integrate. It creates a container that says “you’re welcome here, too” which can heal the parts of us that have been fractured off, helping us remember our wholeness.

At the level of accessing spiritual insight, we can think of safety as a deep trust that who we are is bigger than our ego structure, and that we’ll be okay if we let go of our identification with it. This is very different than not liking yourself and therefore trying to “transcend,” which is still a form of attachment, and often leads to dissociation or unintegrated transcendance. 

There’s an interesting argument to be made that when we feel safe enough to be our full selves (at the level of the ego/self), we actually start to feel safe enough to LET GO of ourselves (because there’s less fear, fighting, and gripping in our being), helping us to access even greater wholeness, one unbounded by our perception of separateness.

While there’s a lot that can be done to facilitate ego safety—good community, self-talk, therapy, and much more—there’s often only so much we can do to facilitate spiritual safety. To feel safe enough to let go of yourself, to really develop the trust that you’ll be okay on the other side of that letting go (to the point that that trust is greater than your ego’s fear), often just requires creating the conditions for stillness and awareness, and then being patient.

Of course, there are ways to accelerate the experience of non-self with hallucinagenics, but that’s a more nuanced conversation.

For now, hopefully this gives you something to think about regarding the role safety plays in personal growth and spiritual pursuits, and how they are still very related.

Thank you for your practice 🙏🏼

I like to work. I get a thrill out of planning out my day, maximizing my minutes, and feeling productive. My work is meaningful to me, and I take it seriously. Which is also why I take my rest seriously. I prioritize sleep, I go for tech-free walks, I meditate, I eat well, and I let my body relax.

I don’t just rest so i can work more (it has intrinsic value and reward) but it does let me show up for my work more fully, inspired, and energized.

Why is rest meaningful to you? And do you take it seriously?

Share a “👍🏼” if you’ve experienced the truth of this in your own life. We often spend most of our time looking toward the external world for comfort, trying to fill inner voids. The external world is important, as we are deeply dependent creatures. But, the incessant arranging and rearranging of the puzzle pieces of your life is both exhausting and momentary in its satisfaction.

How do we become more comfortable with ourselves? Just keep showing up for yourself. Get curious about the part of you that is uncountable being alone, soften into that feeling, show it love, and breathe with it. In time, things will shift.

The questions you ask yourself condition the thoughts in your mind, which condition the emotions in your body, which condition the actions you take. If you ask better questions, you can craft a better life 🙏🏻

If you would like an in-depth, step-by-step course that includes simple practices and mindset shifts to create a more purposeful and fulfilling life, check out my 31-Day Mindfulness and Positive Psychology program 🎧 Each day you’ll receive a new evidence-based teaching and a meditation to help install that teaching 🧠 Link is in my bio 🙏🏻

Digging Vs Going Deeper

One of the 80+ videos in the Practicing Human membership

Your awareness of anger is not angry. Your awareness of fear is not fearful. Your awareness of boredom is not bored.

Labeling the experience that arises is one way to connect to the spacious awareness that KNOWS what is happening, but is not consumed by it.
And, of course, to “become bigger” from the spiritual perspective is more of a “remembering” than a “becoming.”

My experience is that there is an energetic law to surrender: You get back all that you're willing to let go. It may take a different form, you may not get what you “want,” but you will be filled to the extent you are willing to release. You will touch life to the extent you allow yourself to be cracked open.

It just so happens that Surrender took us here.

Thank you for being witness to the journey.

I will continue to live from surrender and share what I learn.

Love,
Cory

Acceptance is a precursor to wise action.
Take this in. It is not to be underestimated.
The Importance of Inner Safety

Performative kindness comes from the mind. It’s an attempt to appear a certain way to others or to yourself. When entrenched further as a patterned part of your identity, it’s a form of distracting yourself from your own pain, or from feeling the pain of others (which actually go hand in hand—you won’t be able to truly open to the pain of others if you are not able to open to your own pain).

The only way to access true kindness is to be vulnerable enough to make contact with your own life. To let life crack you open—in its beauty, messiness, and terror. Here, life will crack through your ego armor designed to buffer you from your raw human experience. It will bring you to your knees, in the most humbling and beautiful way. And when you’re brought down to the dirt, with nothing left to defend, you’ll feel a quiet gratitude for the part of you that opened enough to let everything unravel; for you to make true contact with your life.

You will be able to see others who are also circling that openness, who are terrified to even think about going there.

And you will understand that terror, because you’ve been there, and you know it was only an act of grace that welcomed you to let go in the first place.

So you give them a metaphorical bow of acknowledgment for how hard it is to be alive, and perhaps some softness, warmth, and understanding amidst their edginess and reactivity.

This is true kindness. 

You don’t perform it. You earn the right to experience it.

And, as always, sometimes you still need to put up a boundary, push back, or walk away. And this can all be done with an open heart.

Big love.

Following up on todays post, here’s a clip of one of our daily 10-minute videos in Practicing Human on Performative Kindness. New topics like this, but more in depth, every day for members. Details on how to join in profile.

Here are 3 book recommendations that help you communicate better:

1.) Say What You Mean by @orenjaysofer 

2.) Getting To Zero by @jaysongaddis 

3.) Set Boundaries, Find Peace by @nedratawwab

Before we lose our marbles over this one, let’s break it down.

First, notice how this says “trying to be nice is RARELY a virtue” and “USUALLY” a trauma response. It doesn’t mean it’s never virtuous and always related to trauma (we'll get to that below).

But in my experience, when a person has a patterned behavior of people pleasing, being overly sweet and accommodating, or responds to conflict by saying something like “But I was just trying to be nice!” it’s a survival pattern that developed around a childhood wound of being “too much” or “too angry” or “too loud” or “too (fill in the blank)”

So, to protect ourselves from the backlash of being ourselves we present a more palatable version of who we are to the world, packaged in the presentable, gentle, non-activating box of "being nice."

It's a beautiful survival strategy & we can bow so deeply to the young part of us that put it in place to keep us safe and alive. 

But its still a trauma response, and if we let it run our lives we will continue to suffocate ourselves and project that suffocation onto others as a judgment of "you need to be more calm." 

Of course, the opposite of trying to be nice--e.g. exploding your anger onto someone--is equally a trauma response, so that's not what's being suggested here. There's a middle ground of being able to stay tethered to your true experience without it pushing you into fight, flight, freeze, or fawn. This comes from healing and integration.

(Note: If you want support on this, I recommend my "Taking Up Space" meditation, as well as the “How to Create Inner Safety” and “How to Get Into Alignment” masterclasses, which are all available in Practicing Human Membership. I’ll also be hosting a live Q&A tomorrow for members if you'd like the opportunity to ask a question. Details in my profile) 

I do think "trying to be nice" when done with awareness can be a skillful response to a lot of complicated contextual variables (only you know what those are) OR is connected to cultural norms and not individual trauma (although I'd argue that's still rooted in trauma).

As always, use this post to spark your own reflection. Take what you need and leave the rest.

Big love.

While I recognize and believe in the value of feeling that your life has purpose, I do not feel aligned with the mainstream pressure to have a purpose and the emphasis on trying to create a purpose.

Most of it feels completely mental to me. 

In fact, I think any inquiry into “what is my purpose” is already out of sequence. It’s an attempt to mask pain/uncertainty with a psychological storyline; a buoy that you can hold onto in the dark  oceanic abyss of life.

I also believe that when you’re living a purposeful life, you don’t even need to ask yourself the questions, “What is my purpose?” or “Do I have a purpose?”

It’s not relevant. 

The experience of having purpose just becomes self-evident. It doesn’t need to be shouted. It doesn’t need to be defended. It doesn’t need to be held onto. It’s not buffering you against any aspect of your experience, or buoying you above any pain.

You get there because you met all of yourself, descended beneath the layers of story about who you should be and what you should do, dropped into and through those shadowy places of fear and uncertainty, sensitized yourself to the quiet whispers of your inner being, saw all the ways you’ve abandoned yourself, and fell in love with the opportunity to simply be able to follow the pulse of your life, one beat at a time, because you did the actual work to hear them.

I’m most interested in you connecting to THAT. And supporting you through the big, messy, foggy, confusing journey to get there.

You want purpose? Real, non-mental, bring you to your knees, quaking-in-gratitude-for-life purpose?

It comes from that.

Everything else is psychological masturb*tion.

🫶

And if you’re ready to take that journey with me, first step is to join membership. Live Q&A tonight.

The space of awareness that someone might access in a practice like meditation is not simply a tool that brings your life more into focus. It’s the beginning of seeing that who you are, at your core, is very different & more mysterious than whatever you think or feel.

Prior to connecting to awareness, our identity is anchored into our thoughts and emotions. How we’re doing, and who we perceive ourselves to be, is tied to the changing inner landscape of mental storylines and chemical fluctuations. It’s a rollercoaster.

As you anchor more into awareness, your life not only comes more into focus, but your sense of identity expands, and the activation/charge you feel around those mental storylines and chemical fluctuations begins to quiet.

Humans have taken this training so deep that monks historically practiced self-immolation as a form of protest. Obviously, that’s extreme, and I’m not here to get into a debate about the ethics and logic of it. But what it speaks to is the capacity to be non-reactive and at peace in our experience despite the most intense physical pain.

Not many of us will experience that degree of rootedness in awareness/Self in this lifetime. And I think very few of us are even interested in the journey of getting there.

BUT what would it be like to have more inner space? To feel less charge around your thoughts and emotions? To not feel like your happiness and suffering are entirely dictated by circumstances outside of your control? 

This is VERY much possible.

And it’s a beautiful journey to begin.

There are lots of resources to support you in the process if you have the intention.

If you would like support from me specifically, I highly recommend the “Working With Thoughts” digital course and/or joining Practicing Human membership. Both are in my profile.

Big love.

p.s. I do not take the stance that you should always be calm & peaceful, not that that's the highest aspiration. So please do not weaponize this post against yourself or anyone else having big emotional experiences. There is an important role for having permission to feel what you’re feeling, and it’s way more rooted in what I’m talking about in this post than we think.
Permission for all of it.

Have you felt the difference between “saving” others and “serving” them? Feel free to share any more thoughts you might have on this.

Also, tag some folks who would appreciate hearing this distinction 🙏🏻

And if you’d like free, daily text message teachings and practices on mindfulness, mental health, and self-love, text the word “Instagram” to 1-631-305-2874 to receive free, daily text and audio message teachings, quotes, and insights delivered to your phone 📲
Different phases of our awakening and healing journey call for different approaches. Be wary of any guide or modality that only emphasizes transcendence and doesn’t make room for your messiness.
A few lines on control and surrender

Cultivating stillness is not about privileging stillness over movement. It’s about having the capacity to be still amidst the ongoing stream of your patterns and impulses. It’s about choice.

If you want support cultivating stillness, I have a library of meditations, courses, and teachings in Practicing Human membership. More details in my profile.
Following the soul’s whisper is seldom without grief.

Performative confidence comes from the ego. And the ego is a set of beliefs about who we need to be and how we need to act in order to be safe, loved, and praised. Ego confidence requires the validation of others, which is why it’s showy and performative.

This does not mean if you have true confidence that you do not share your skills or values. If you run a business, this requires you to “advertise” yourself. And a fear around sharing your worth is just as much an ego move as performative sharing of your value.

But there’s a difference between sharing who you are from a place of “This is what I can offer, I believe it’s impactful, and you can make your own decision about if there’s something here for you or not” vs “This is what I can offer, you should love me for it, and I need your praise to feel settled.”

Real confidence has a receptive, magnetic energy. Performative confidence has a graspy, outward energy.
Love.
